title: DataStax Presents:  A Fireside Chat with Joseph Jacks on Open Source Capital and Company Startup...
description:
Join us for a chat with Joseph Jacks (JJ) about his new venture into open source company venture funding with OSS Capital (https://twitter.com/OSSCapital). JJ has had a super active history in open source and as an entrepreuner. In this chat he answers questions around what he's looking at for funding, and what he sees around Kubernetes, discusses various Apache Projects like Kafka, and multiple others. Delving into various funding paths and further stepping into different open source technologies and respective funding cycles and related patterns.


ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 6
DataStax  powers  the  Right-Now  Enterprise  with  the  always-on,  distributed  cloud  database  built  on  Apache  Cassandra™  and designed for hybrid cloud. DataStax Enterprise 6 (DSE 6) includes industry-leading performance, self-driving operational simplicity, and robust analytics.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise-6

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax | https://twitter.com/datastax-academy
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/datastax
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX ACADEMY
On the DataStax Academy YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax Enterprise©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

some data pipelines are very real-time centric and streaming centric so you're taking in data from like clique streams or log data or some fast moving source that is sort of funneling the these sort of changes to the data into some kind of real time online pipeline and you might be using some publish/subscribe mechanism or some streaming queue or some message bus or something to process all that information and do transformations and and manipulations against the data whereas other types of pipelines are very batch offline centric so you're taking in some files or you're taking in some chunks of data from some data warehouse or something and then you're running batch operations bash pipeline so there's two different types of fundamentally different types of data processing workload with Apache beam the reason I asked about Apache beam is battery beam has an interesting model where it sort of fuses and combines the two types of paradigms in one architecture and this architecture is called the data flow model or data flow architectures it's a it's a sort of semantics or an approach to data processing as a paradigm that Google wrote about a few years ago and they had a paper published on that patchy beam is an open-source software implementation of the data flow model and data flow basically says that you can take as input to a pipeline real-time or batch sources of data but you really treat everything as a stream of data but in order to do batch processing on it you just kind of window or you have what's called a bounded snapshot or a context bounded sort of snapshot of that data and then you run transformations against sort of a window in time of a stream of events coming into a pipeline but data flow or the beam model basically says that everything is a data stream everything is a real-time kind of event stream coming into something like the data flow the data flow pipeline what the beam project then does is after you have your data coming into the data pipeline you construct a directed graph of the pipeline itself and all the steps in the pipeline and what you want what you want to do in terms of transformation and all the different processing logic in that pipeline but what beam allows you to do is in each step of the data pipeline you can actually activate or you can invoke a different data processing back-end or a different data processing technology so in one step of a beam dag pipeline you could be doing some processing in Kafka and then the output from that data in Kafka using some type of transformation function in Kafka or some publish/subscribe transformation could then go into another step in the beam model which could be doing something in maybe meet maybe tension flow and then the output from that after running some machine learning inferencing on that that data could be you know running into another step in the die which could be something in Apache spark for example so each of these data processing backends have different ways of manipulating real-time or batch data and being sort of lets you mix and match those different backends well what we've been working on is is a way to sort of simplify that
